meta.headline: I Kissed A Girl & I Liked It
meta.subhed: A story about hearing yourself represented in music for the first time and chasing that high ever since
meta.byline2:
with data analysis help from Kelsey Campbell
and illustrations by Lace Garcia

prose1.value: In a time when the soundtrack to your life is built on a mountain of â€œfirsts:â€
ğŸ’” First heartbreak: Eric Claptonâ€™s â€œWonderful Tonight.â€
Those 8 problematically-presented words became a secret anthem â€” the first time I heard a woman openly singing about another woman.

The first radio station to play â€œI Kissed a Girlâ€ was Nashvilleâ€™s 107.5 â€œThe River,â€ or stereo preset No. 6 in my very inconspicuous first car: a lime green Pontiac Sunfire. When I heard it, I was floored. This? In the â€œBuckle of the Bible Beltâ€ in a state that, to this day, has some of the most vile anti- queer and transgender laws? I immediately downloaded it and burned a CD.

At 3 minutes long, I could listen to the defiant bass line about 16 times on the 50-minute drive it took to get to the â€œsecond-closestâ€ Best Buy two towns over. Driving those extra minutes and that extra town ensured that I could snag the equally inconspicuous flaming pink-boxed first season of L Word without waving a giant rainbow flag and raising any questions about my sexuality. I wasnâ€™t ready. At least not yet.

prose2.value: But, it turned out that â€œI Kissed a Girlâ€ wasnâ€™t just something I was singing with my car windows rolled up, it was something everyone was scream-singing at the top of their lungs. It was a certified top-of-the-charts bop. I wasnâ€™t fully convinced of mainstream acceptance, but it at least seemed like mainstream permission.

For as groundbreaking as it felt to hear a woman explicitly singing about being with another woman then, it would take another 13 years for a man explicitly singing about being with another man to top the charts.

prose3.value: Then came Lil Nas Xâ€™s â€œMONTERO (Call Me By Your Name).â€

This time thereâ€™s no drunken permission: ğŸµâ€œI got so brave, drink in handâ€ğŸµ. No hint at a phase or a fling: ğŸµâ€œYou're my experimental gameâ€ğŸµ. No fetishisation of the male gaze: ğŸµâ€œI hope my boyfriend don't mind itâ€ğŸµ.
Just a Black queer artist unapolgetically owning it: ğŸµâ€œI want that jet lag from fuckin' and flyin', Shoot a child in your mouth while I'm ridin'â€ğŸµ
Itâ€™s going to be a soundtrack â€œfirstâ€ for so many people. And it made me wonder: how many songs about same-gender relationships make it to the mainstream? So, I went there.

prose4.song: Since Katy Perryâ€™s 2008 â€œgay-for-payâ€ bop, we found 7 other songs that appeared in the year-end Billboard Hot 100 with <mark class=gender-highlight>explicit same-gender lyrics</mark>.
Lady Gagaâ€™s 2009 bisexual anthemâ€œPoker Faceâ€ where she coins the phrase â€œbluffin' with my muffinâ€ and sings about being with a man, but fantisizing about being with a woman:
prose4.lyrics:
ğŸµNo, he can't read my poker face,
(She's got me like nobody)ğŸµ

prose4.song: Britney Spearsâ€™ 2009 wordplay hit â€œIf You Seek Amyâ€ (say it slowly) where she sings:
prose4.lyrics: ğŸµAll of the boys and all of the girls are begging to, if you seek AmyğŸµ

prose4.lyrics:
ğŸµMy love, my love, my love,
She keeps me warm.ğŸµ

prose4.lyrics:
ğŸµ I wanna taste her lips, yeah,
'cause they taste like you ğŸµ

prose4.lyrics:

And I thought that she could really be the one this time ğŸµ

Ice on the cake when I bake itğŸµ

prose5.value: Thatâ€™s 0.7%. Eight songs (not even one a year) out of 1,157 unique hits. And ALL of them feature a woman explicitly singing about another woman using words like â€œsheâ€, â€œherâ€, and â€œgirlâ€ â€” until now.

Iâ€™m making some assumptions to say that â€œMONTERO (Call Me By Your Name)â€ will appear on the 2021 year-end Billboard Hot 100 charts, but itâ€™s well within reach. Lil Nas Xâ€™s queer anthem has already spent 9 weeks on the charts. The No. 100 songs from the last 3 years average about 20 weeks in the Hot 100.

Out queer artists like Janelle MonÃ¡e, Frank Ocean, Kelani, Hayler Kiyoko, Troye Sivan, and JoJo Siwa havenâ€™t cracked the year-end Billboard Hot 100 with solo songs yet, but even when queer artists do reach the pinacle of pop mainstream they rarely sing about same-gender relationships.

Between 2008â€“2020, 135 songs featuring an openly queer artist appeared on the year-end Top 100 charts. Only 5 (3.7%) include explicit same gender lyrics. Hereâ€™s a look at openly queer artists with more than 5 year-end Billboard Hot 100 appearances. Click on the blocks to see the song and sample lyrics.

prose6.value: Of course, queer lyrics arenâ€™t limited to same-gender references, but theyâ€™re often the most sanitized and direct version that a mainstream audience recognizes and is exposed to.

Artists like Halsey, Lady Gaga, and Cardi B are openly bisexual so singing about relationships with BOTH men and women is queer. And artists like Demi Lovato, Sam Smith, and Miley Cyrus are non-binary or genderfluid, so when they do sing about relationships itâ€™s queer. And there are plenty of other queer lyrics that donâ€™t explicitly reference gender at all.

As someone firmly planted in my queer identity now (I have a wife, we have a rainbow flag in front of our home, I watch a lot of womenâ€™s sports) itâ€™s easy for me to catch enuedos, nods, and winks like Lovatoâ€™s ğŸµâ€œGot a taste for the cherry, I just need to take a biteâ€ğŸµ or Lil Nas Xâ€™s ğŸµâ€œI might bottom on the low, but I top shit,â€ğŸµ but thinking back to who I was when I first heard â€œI Kissed a Girl,â€ I might not have recognized myself in these songs unless someone pointed a giant flashing neon rainbow arrow at it.

It reminds me of a line from a Dave Holmes piece about Taylor Swiftâ€™s the â€œvague call for toleranceâ€ that was â€œYou Need to Calm Down:â€ â€œ...in a bedroom somewhere in the world, some young person is getting a desperately-needed window into a life that suits them, and I am legitimately thrilled for that kid.â€
And thatâ€™s what music can do. It can be someoneâ€™s â€œhundredthâ€ or â€œthousandthâ€ or â€œnot-far-enough,â€ AND it can be someoneâ€™s â€œfirst.â€

method.value: This project began in 2019. We were taunted with songs like Sam Smith and Demi Lovato's â€œIâ€™m Readyâ€ and Miley Cyrusâ€™ â€œMidnight Skyâ€ until Lil Nas X released â€œMONTERO (Call Me By Your Name)â€ and we were confident in a narrative path forward.

We collected year-end Hot 100 songs from Billboard. Then we researched each artistâ€™s sexual orientation and gender identity with a mixed programmatic/manual approach that looked at Wikipedia pages, news articles, and social media profiles. We built 3 dictionaries: one to flag feminine gendered lyrics like â€œwomenâ€, â€œgirlâ€, â€œherâ€, and â€œsheâ€; one to flag masculine gendered lyrics like â€œmanâ€, â€œboyâ€, â€œhisâ€, and â€œheâ€; and one to flag relationship lyrics like â€œloveâ€, â€œheartâ€, â€œkissâ€, â€œsexâ€.

We used lyrics from an existing corpus and filled in gaps from Genius. Each song was tagged by whether it contained feminined gendered lyrics, masculine gendered lyrics, and relationship lyrics. Then those tags were compared to the artistâ€™s sexual orientation and gender identity. This gave us a set of songs to manually check. From there we listened to A LOT of music to identify the 8 songs with explicit same-gender relationship lyrics. Think we missed anything? Email Jan at jan@pudding.cool.
